data.text:
First of all, kudos for being one of the few people left in our business willing to have an opinion! It‚Äôs interesting that we saw the Kate Hudson performance on the Howard Stern show. Although I maintain he is still the best to ever sit behind a radio mic, now that he has essentially become accepted as a mainstream celebrity, he has gone from the ultimate example of not giving a sh*t, to often kissing the ass of his fellow celebrity club members. Now to Kate Husdon, the rock star. As an actress, she was good in Almost Famous which I attribute largely to her being quite young and Cameron Crowe doing an excellent job. But because I travel a lot, and refuse to watch good movies on crappy airplane screens, I have had the dubious pleasure of watching some of ‚ÄúBride Wars‚Äù and ‚ÄúHow to Lose a Guy in 10 Days‚Äù. It would be hard to be more annoying than she was in those films. And now she has to bring that same mediocre acting talent to music. (I can only assume that Chris Robinson feels he dodged a bullet). So for people who are exclaiming that she can sing ‚Ä¶ yes, perhaps compared to someone who is tone deaf. I have spent a career coaching and producing young singers. There is a real giveaway as to who is imitating a performance, and who is the real thing. Undeveloped singers have what I call ‚Äúvocal ticks‚Äù, little mannerisms they think sound cool but they overuse because they don‚Äôt really know what they are doing. Kate Hudson dips the pitch at the end of EVER SINGLE NOTE! Once you realize this, you can‚Äôt unhear it. Listen to a great singer like Bonnie Raitt, sometimes when it is emotionally effective, she will dip a note, but it has impact because she only does it sometimes! It is the same thing with all the ridiculous flourishes & melismas you hear on American Idol ‚Ä¶ did Aretha or Stevie do it, yes, when it counted, not constantly. That is certainly not my only complaint with the superfluous new music from yet another famous person ‚Ä¶ but it is a start.Thanks again for being willing to call this trifle out.

Steve Postell

On celebrities or actors doing albums I‚Äôd say the end year was 2010.

I signed Hugh Laurie to Warners when I ran Warner Music Entertainment. Hugh is a blues pianist and vocalist and he can really play!

We made a beautiful New Orleans inspired album ‚ÄúLet Them Talk‚Äù with Joe Henry, a PBS ‚ÄúGreat Performances‚Äù special and sold close to 2m copies globally (across that album and the follow up).

But it was a different time.

TV still sold albums. Retail still sold albums.

It was the year YouTube started to really make traction with Spotify hard on its heels. Times were changing.

Many, many labels copied what we‚Äôd done with Hugh in subsequent years and almost without exception they failed.

Now I‚Äôm indie and running a label doing the modern equivalent. We sign artists with fan bases growing fast on socials. It‚Äôs the same thing as I did at WMG, but re-cut for the 2020s. Go where the audience is and amplify.

We do 200m streams a month and 90% of our signings are profitable.

#movewiththetimes

Love your work!

Conrad Withey

CEO

The Kate Hudson thing is the epitome of modern day, good ol‚Äô USA. Her money and celebrity let her cut to the front of the line. So boring, but round and round we go.

I‚Äôve run a record label (Royal Potato Family) for 15 years. I‚Äôve put out countless amazing, supremely inspired, enduring records. I‚Äôve never looked at all the indicators. I‚Äôve always signed artists and released records by my gut, what I hear, how it makes me feel and my belief that it can bring something sustinent to others. But aside from a small loyal audience, it‚Äôs impossible to get any attention or traction ‚Äì even our distributor doesn‚Äôt care. It‚Äôs only about numbers and $$. Nobody even listens ‚Äì people in fancy offices, making lots of money and all they can say is get a TikTok page, get more likes on social media. I have to always be working four or five other jobs ‚Äì PR, management, consulting, etc. to keep the dream alive. Everyday, wake up, roll the stone back up hill.

I‚Äôm sure most people would respond by saying I suck, my artists suck, play the game better, stop whining. Release something that masses want and the masses will come. Fair enough. I get it. We‚Äôre not entitled to anything. Live by the sword, die by the sword. We‚Äôll keep pushing. That small community of people who care will be enough. There are some brilliant artists, with pure artistic expression, who still break through. But it‚Äôs getting tougher everyday. I can‚Äôt help but think collectively we‚Äôd be doing a little better if quality mattered as much as the fastest path to money. I‚Äôm not sure how much longer those of us who embrace that notion can financially sustain without more reach. Never mind the mental health aspect. Speaking for myself, I‚Äôll keep going. Maybe I completely burn out and have to take a job as a barista. At least I went for it.

I‚Äôm not even sure what point I‚Äôm trying to make anymore other than there are still some of us out here for whom artists who‚Äôve toiled over their craft, write songs that speak to our human condition, get in a room together and create music that vibrates with both the trials and beauty of life, is everything. We put on records and we feel better for 22 minutes. It makes the world a richer, more vibrant place and is a bridge for soulful people with open hearts in their day to day lives.

This leads me back to Kate Hudson. She has every right to make a record and put her artistic vision into the world. But it‚Äôs the access, the dumb f*cking corporate hacks who care about nothing but money and celebrity, who amplify her at the expense of those way more compelling who should be getting that opportunity. Again, I get it. It‚Äôs the way of the world, nothing my bitching is gonna do to change it. But it‚Äôs heartbreaking.

Listen to this Chris Kasper record we put out today. If it was 1973, it might stand a chance.

Kevin Calabro

Royal Potato Family

PS ‚Äì I was Chris Robinson‚Äôs publicist for five years.
